Describe the structure and organization of the judiciary and how judges are appointed and removed. Give examples of the powers and responsibilities of the judiciary and how they interact with the executive and legislative branches of government. P long Jar pipeline pressure Gill HE
generated_output:
AD of JUDICIARY: MILAN TEPIČ ANSWERS: The judiciary serves as the guardian of the rule of law, constitutional rights and freedoms, and the protection of human, constitutional and social interests. Its role is to resolve disputes between subjects of human rights and state organs, as well as between individuals. The judiciary interprets the law, ensuring its consistency with ethical and moral standards in order to limit arbitrariness and abuse of power. The judiciary is a guardian of constitutional values and human rights, and as such also assumes a responsibility to protect the freedom and democratic space of human society from threats such as authoritarianism, totalitarianism, and despotism. The basic characteristic of the judiciary is its institutionalized separation from other organs of state power and parliament, which helps to prevent it from being co-opted by other institutions in power. The judiciary is organized into two branches: ordinary courts and the Supreme Court: • The ordinary courts are composed of a basic judicial body, and these courts are divided into courts located at the provincial level and courts located at the republic level. Judges in basic judicial colleges are appointed by the Chief Judge with the consent of the National Assembly and for the duration of judicial office; they may be reappointed, but they must reapply for each renewal. The ordinary courts determine the basic rules of criminal and civil procedure. • The Supreme Court is the judicial branch of the state, consisting of the Constitutional Chamber, the Civil Law Chamber, Criminal Law Chamber, Commercial Law Chamber and the Administrative and Tax Law Chamber. Judges in the Supreme Court are appointed by the President and confirmed by the National Assembly for the duration of judicial office and may be re-appointed for new mandate, but they must each reapply for it. The Supreme Court is the final instance in legal disputes and reviews the practice of the ordinary courts and establishes legal standards that regulate criminal and civil procedure, and legal practice. • The constitutional body of the judiciary is the Constitutional Court, appointed by the National Assembly, consisting of 13 judges who hold 9-year term. Judges are appointed with the opinion of the Supreme Judicial Council. The Constitutional Court establishes whether the Constitution, the European Union Law, the Constitutional Act and the law are compliant with the Constitution in accordance with the Constitutional Act, when it is requested by the President of the Republic or the National Assembly; • The legislative body of the judiciary system is the National Judicial Council, which consists of 13 judges and five members of the National Assembly. The National Judicial Council appoints a Chief Prosecutor and judges of the Supreme Court. The judges of the Constitutional Court and Supreme Court may be dismissed by the National Judicial Council, with the approval of the Supreme Judicial Council of Slovenia. The judicial system in Slovenia is largely organized according to principles of the organizational autonomy of the judiciary, which ensures the separation between the judiciary and other state institutions and their organizational autonomy. There are three organs of the judiciary through which the judiciary fulfils its duties. The first is the Supreme Court, the basic competent organ with which citizens usually have dealings with on matters related to the judicial process. The second is the Constitutional Court, the organ through which the National Assembly or the President of the Republic may request an interpretation of the constitutionality of an act, and in the case of the infringement of human rights, the right to legal remedy. The third is the National Court, the organizational judicial body that determines the basic rules of criminal and civil procedure. The Constitutional Court is also called the highest judicial instance, where the disputes of ordinary courts in Slovenia are resolved. The Constitutional Court is the body through which judicial control is exercised on the Constitution. It also examines international agreements in which jurisdiction was transferred, reviews the Constitution of the Republic of Slovenia, and examines the conformity of the Constitution with the Constitutional Act (Constitutional Protocol), international agreements and EU acts. The Constitutional Court is composed of 13 judges, who are appointed and removed by the National Assembly, which is requested to do so by two thirds of all representatives in the Assembly. 2/3 of the members of the Constitutional Court must come from among lawyers and judges, while the remaining third are composed of professors in law, sociologists and economists. Members are appointed by the National Assembly, based on a candidate nominated by a council of experts and approved by the National Assembly. The Constitutional Court examines and decides upon applications by the President of the Republic, the National Assembly, the Government and at least 25 (and no more than 30) members of the National Assembly on a constitutional matter. Judges of the Republic of Slovenia, as part of their functions, also take on the role of presidents or deputy presidents of the Slovenian delegation in international organizations in which Slovenia is a party or a signatory state, where international criminal law is also applied, and where the Slovenian judicial system is represented. For example, members of judges of the Republic of Slovenia are also members of an expert group that will prepare the European Union on matters relating to the implementation of the United Nations Convention on international crimes. The following are examples of how a state or/and international court have ruled on human rights violations: The European Court of Human Rights ruled in favor of the UK in 1978 following the failure of the British government to investigate the illegal abduction, detention, torture and forced confessions of three Spanish civil rights activists by the security forces of the State of Argentina in 1977. It was argued that “the right to liberty and security of the person contained in Article 5 (art. 5) was violated as no effective investigation has taken place”. 11 The European Court of Human Rights ruled that the French state was in breach of its obligation to respect freedom of expression in relation to a demonstration against the ban on wearing headscarves in the French public sector. The court ruled in favor of the application filed by a young student after having been convicted of disrespect to the flag and to the memory of deceased soldiers on the basis that “the criminal conviction was punished by imprisonment and a fine, and was thus deemed a violation of Article 10 (article. 10), as no important public interest justifies criminal sanctions for certain forms of criticism. criticism of public institutions”. It follows that the court ruled that states must protect both the rights of individuals to exercise their freedom of expression and the rights of others to have their rights protected. 12 The European Court of Human Rights ruled in its judgment of 2005, in relation to the cases Nino Kostanidzes against Latvia (Article 3 (art. 3) and Article 14 (art. 14) of the European Convention of Human Rights) that the ban on the sale of alcohol to minors is proportional. The main focus of the court was the ban, which banned the distribution of alcohol to persons under the age of 18 without a valid ID. It was stated by the court that: “The Court emphasizes the importance of banning the sale of alcohol to minors in order to protect society as a whole from harm and the serious public order threat posed by intoxication among young people. Moreover, the Court finds that the ban on selling and advertising alcohol in relation to underage individuals to persons under the age of 18 is proportional. This is due to the fact that according to statistics of the State Medical Administration of Latvia, 14,000 people, or more than a quarter of all deaths among young people, are due to acute alcoholic intoxication. The ban has been established for a number of other states within the Council of Europe, including in particular France and Germany. It is also part of the internal regulations of the European Parliament and of the European Parliament. According to the European Court of Human Rights, this legislation is in line with the principles of the European Convention on Human Rights. 13

According to Chapter I of the Constitution of the Independent State of Samoa 1966, there is an independent judicial system, headed by the Chief Justice. For the purpose of this assignment, please refer to Part 3 of the Constitution and Chapter 5 of the Constitution Act, 1962 or the relevant legislation which relates to the judiciary in your country.
The head of the judiciary of the Independent State of Samoa is the Supreme Court, consisting of the Chief Justice and the two other judges appointed by the Head of State and the Privy Council and which is made up of the High Court, the District Court, and the Magistrates Court. The power to appoint judges to the Samoa Supreme Court is vested in the Head of State of the Independent State of Samoa and the Privy Council and all judges may be removed from office by the Head of State of the Independent State of Samoa and the Privy Council after consultation with the Council of Cabinet Ministers.
The appointment of judges to the Supreme Court shall be by His Excellency the Head of State of the Independent State of Samoa in accordance with the advice of His Excellency the Head of State of the Independent State of Samoa and the Privy Council with the prior approval of the Council of Cabinet Ministers. The Privy Council shall have the power to remove any judge from office, after consultation with the Council of Cabinet Ministers, and any judge who is removed from office pursuant to this provision may appeal such decision of the Privy Council to the next succeeding head of state of the Independent State of Samoa. All judges may resign from the Supreme Court under the conditions prescribed in an instrument to be approved by the Council of Government.
In determining its policy with respect to the constitution of the Supreme Court, the Privy Council shall have regard to the extent to which those to be appointed to the Supreme Court possess qualifications, training or experience that will enable them, in the furtherance of public interest, to render such service to the independent state of Samoa as the state may require and to fulfil the obligations of the independent state of Samoa to the external territories and dependent territories or territories under the control of the Privy Council of the independent State of Samoa. The Privy Council may make such recommendations as it deems appropriate in regard to appointments to the independent State of Samoa.

Ans.Defamation: In a legal sense, the word defamation refers to a false communication that damages a person's reputation. Under common law, defamation can occur regardless of an individual's motive. Defamation is also known as "defamation of character" or a "slander.". There are three main types of defamation: Libel: A libel is written or published communication that damages a person's reputation. Slander: A slander is a spoken communication that damages a person's reputation. Injurious Falsehood: Injurious falsehood occurs when a person intentionally makes a false statement that causes harm to another individual. In some states, injurious falsehood may also include statements that are not false but are still harmful. For example, if someone were to spread rumors about a competitor's pricing strategy and that led to the competitor's laying off employees or closing its doors entirely, this would likely qualify as actionable in a defamation suit.. Defamation per se: In some states, defamation can be considered defamation per se if it falls into select categories such as a) implying that someone has contracted a sexually transmitted disease; b) implying that someone committed a crime; c) implying that someone has engaged in immoral behavior; or d) implying that someone is mentally ill. To prove defamation per se, the plaintiff must show that either (a) the statements were false, (b) there was no reasonable
(Instructions for Frank) The article written by Frank and published in the newspaper is considered defamatory because it causes George's reputation to be harmed. George's reputation is damaged as a result of the false statement that he is involved in a corruption scandal and that he had an affair with his secretary. In order to succeed in his claim, George would have to prove that the statements made by Frank were false, even if he did not intend to harm George's reputation. Frank, on the other hand, could potentially win the case by arguing his defense of truth or that he had a right to exercise his freedom of speech. The elements of defamation that George must prove to succeed in his claim are: a) False statement: The defamatory statement must be proven as false before damages can be awarded for defamation of character (libel) or injury to a reputation (slander). b) Reasonable care should have been taken when making the statement. This means that if someone makes a false statement about another person, they must take reasonable care to make sure that the statement is true before publishing/communicating it. Otherwise, they may be held liable for defamation or even libel suit. c) Injury/harm caused to the plaintiff's reputation/economic standing because of false statements made by another person. To succeed in this case on elements 2 and 3, George must show that there has been sufficient injury/harm caused to his reputation/economic standing because of false statements made by another

instruction: What is the relationship between sleep apnea and cardiovascular disease? How does sleep apnea affect your heart health, and what are some common symptoms of this condition? What are some treatment options available for sleep apnea?
prompt: P longHOME pipelinebel Gill HE
combined_input: What is the relationship between sleep apnea and cardiovascular disease? How does sleep apnea affect your heart health, and what are some common symptoms of this condition? What are some treatment options available for sleep apnea? P longHOME pipelinebel Gill HE
generated_output:
ILIE
What is sleep apnea and can it cause heart disease?
Sleep apnea is a condition where a person stops breathing for a period of time during the night. This can happen because the person has a blockage in their airway, or maybe because they are not getting enough oxygen from their lungs.
When someone sleep apnea (has breathing problems), their heart has to pump extra hard in order to get enough oxygen to get through the night. This can lead to high blood pressure, heart attack, or stroke.
Sleep apnea is found more often in men than women, and it usually starts before age 55. Some people with sleep apnea also have high blood pressure, obesity, or diabetes.
There are several treatments available for sleep apnea, including lifestyle changes like losing weight and getting more exercise; using CPAP (constant positive airway pressure) machines; mouthpieces; medicines; surgery; etc..
What is a heart attack? What is heart failure?
A heart attack occurs when the blood flow to your heart is cut off due to a blockage in an artery. This can lead to chest pain, shortness of breath, and sweating. Heart failure is a condition where the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the needs of your body.
Heart disease can cause heart attacks or heart failure. There are many different types of heart disease, and the risks of each one depend on your age, health, and family history.
Some people who have heart disease may not feel any signs or symptoms. However, others may have chest pain that seems like it’s happening all over the body; a fast or irregular heartbeat; or difficulty breathing or swallowing.
If you’re worried about your heart health, make an appointment with a cardiologist to learn more about the risks and treatment options for you.
What is the difference between diabetes and hyperglycemia?
There is no difference between diabetes and hyperglycemia. Diabetes refers to a condition in which the pancreas does not produce enough insulin or the body’s cells are not responsive to it. Hyperglycemia, or high blood sugar, occurs when blood sugar levels become too high for the body to manage them effectively.
In most cases both diabetes and hyperglycemia will be present together, but each affect people differently. The symptoms can include fatigue, increased thirst or hunger, frequent urination, blurred vision, weight loss, nausea or vomiting, and muscle or joint pain.
If you have both conditions then you may be referred to a specialist to find out if medication can help you manage your blood sugar levels better.
What are the effects of sleep apnea on heart disease?
There is an increased risk for heart disease associated with sleep apnea. Sleep apnea is a condition where people have difficulty breathing at night, usually because they stop breathing for short periods of time.
This can lead to elevated blood pressure and increased risk for heart disease.

“PIPE LINES AND PUMPING STATION RELIABILITY”
“Reliability based maintenance (RBM) is one of the methods that incorporates the idea that assets need to be taken care of proactively by providing and prioritizing maintenance measures on the basis of the likelihood of failure (Garry et al. 2007). The failure model used for RBM is the one proposed by the Canadian Standards Association (CSA, 1998; 97, p.392)
Figure 1 Reliability Based Maintenance Framework
Garry et al. (2007) stated that the model is used by engineering organizations worldwide to manage assets reliably and predict their failures (p. 347) . The core of the model is that maintenance must be performed when the probability of failure exceeds a certain value. From my perspective, the value of failure is considered an economical threshold value. Once the probability of failure exceeds a certain economical threshold defined in terms of lost production hours, the assets will be taken care of or replaced. So, the aim of the reliability based maintenance (RBM) is to define this economical threshold value. Garry et al. (2008, p.401) highlight that it is very difficult to establish economical failure probabilities and to calculate failure rates accurately. The RBM method helps to overcome this difficulty when managing the maintenance process of a pipeline. RBM uses life prediction tools which can help in determining the appropriate maintenance strategy. The method developed by Garry et al. ( 2008) uses statistical analyses to predict failure rates and failure probabilities. They point out that statistical methods are the most applicable to failure forecasting. The model proposed by Garry et al. (2008) helps to estimate the life of the assets at different levels of safety. In addition, it helps to identify critical components of the pipeline system and to provide an economical replacement. RBM uses reliability models to support the replacement decision which is usually the final objective of the model developed by Garry et al. (2008).” (AH. M., & K. R., 2016, p.373)

Assignment: 6.11 The Cost Concepts
Instructions: Using the information from the course project and the attached document, “Cost_Concepts_and_Beh.docx”, and write an essay to answer the questions below.
1-1. “Explain the difference between the concepts of value and cost.”
The difference between the concepts of value and cost in terms of economic profits and social production functions is the only difference in the concepts. Other than that, the difference between the two concepts is that it defines what is the cost of a good or a service. In simple words, we use the terms value and cost interchangeably, but, value and cost are distinct in the way they have no real meaning outside of an economic function.
The concept of economic profit is only the difference between the cost and the marginal revenue associated with a production function. For instance, when the profit is economic and the price is $2, the total profit of the firm is (MR – cost). When the price is $0, the total profit of the firm is 0.
As a result, cost is the expenses a business must incur to be profitable. Thus, profit is the excess income of a firm over the sum of the cost of producing the commodity. The term “cost is considered a general term that can be used across all fields of economic study and business decisions. For example, one might inquire about the cost of the product instead of asking about the money paid to purchase it.
1-2”What are the most important costs of business in your field?”
Operating expense: Operating expenses are the actual expenses incurred in the operations of the business. Some businesses may choose to include operating expenses as assets or liabilities on their balance sheet. All businesses, from a restaurant that serves food to a business producing consumer goods, have operating expenses. Operating expenses are the direct expenses a business must incur to keep its doors open and running profitably.
Personnel Expenses: Personnel expenses are the wages paid to employees. It includes the gross wage an employee receives from their employer and any payroll deductions. Personnel expenses also include employer contributions to benefit plans such as healthcare and retirement. In addition, personnel expenses include employer payments into unemployment insurance, social security, workers’ compensation, or other social security systems. These payroll-related costs are also known as payroll tax expenses. Personnel expense is more often referred to as personnel expense (PE).
Capital Expense: Capital expenditures are the amounts a business spends on long-term assets used in the company’s core operations. To purchase an asset, you must typically make a financial investment. If the investment is long-term, then it’s a capital expenditure. A business can use capital to buy anything from a vehicle and a desk to a patent and new machinery.
Selling, General & Administrative Expense, or SG&A: Selling, General, and Administrative expense (SG&A) is a type of cost allocated from profits to various expenses incurred by a company. It is generally a non-operating type of cost that is a cost incurred. Under GAAP, SG&A are not considered capital expenses but are categorized as operating expenses.
Taxes: Costs associated with taxes are those that are related to various tax payments. However, if the government exempts you from paying taxes, your taxes are not taxes. Thus, for example, if you own stock in a company, you often receive dividend payments. However, the government sometimes taxes what is paid in dividend payments. As a result, your dividend payments are not taxes. In contrast, if you must pay taxes to the government, then what the government extracts from you is a tax.
Wages: Wages are any amounts paid for labor, including payroll taxes. Salary and benefits are included along with wages. Wages may be paid to both exempt and non-exempt workers. It also includes employee payroll taxes, benefits, and bonuses. Wages are included in the expense category of the income statement.
Insurance Costs: Insurance costs generally refer to liability insurance. You purchase liability insurance to cover yourself when someone sues. Some of the costs in insurance fees are policy annual costs, premiums, and claims.
Commissions: Commissions are payments made to a person who acts as an agent or broker between a principal and a third party in sales or services. The commissions are generally a percentage of the gross transaction price and are paid to the agent or broker on behalf of the principal. The principal may also be required to reimburse the agent or broker for certain expenses incurred in carrying out the sales or services.
Depreciation: Depreciation is typically an expense that affects the amount of the cost of a new business asset deducted in each accounting period. Thus, by the time the asset is sold or traded in for a new one, the deduction has been fully expensed. In contrast, when the asset is fully depreciated, it is depreciated further. Thus, an expense that will not be deducted from income in future periods is a depreciation expense.
Financial Costs: The financial costs of financing the acquisition of long-term assets such as mortgages are a form of financial cost. The financial costs also include the cost of leasing and hiring capital.
Marketing Costs: The primary types of marketing costs are advertising, sales promotions, and general publicity. These can be fixed, ongoing, or variable, and all are cost measures.
Profit: Profit refers to the difference between the income and the expense of a business. Profit is important because it measures the company’s efficiency and profitability. Profit can be used in analyzing a company’s finances and can be used to determine whether a company is making a profit or not.
Insurance Costs: Insurance costs may arise as insured losses, the cost of the insurance policy, and adjustment expenses. The insurance cost may also be paid by the insurer, who then may pass on the increased reinsurance rate to the policyholder.
Interest: Interest is the cost paid to lenders for the use of money. It is the cost of borrowing money. Interest may be paid on loans such as mortgages, car loans, student loans, or personal loans. The interest may also be paid on savings and investments.
Taxes on Business: A tax on a business is a cost levied on a company’s profit. In some countries, the tax is levied on companies’ income. In others, the tax is a fixed percentage of the company’s revenue. Taxes on businesses may not be considered to be a tax. Thus, tax law often requires companies to disclose the tax they pay to the government, regardless of whether the tax was a tax or a cost.
Costs associated with taxes are those that are related to various tax payments. However, if the government exempts you from paying taxes, your taxes are not taxes. Thus, for example, if you own stock in a company, you often receive dividend payments. However, the government sometimes taxes what is paid in dividend payments. As a result, your dividend payments are not taxes. In contrast, if you must pay taxes to the government, then what the government extracts from you is a tax.
Costs: Cost is any amount of money spent to produce a good or service. Costs include all the resources used and the expenses incurred to create a product or service. Cost could also be used to describe a product’s value relative to its competition. Costs are expenses associated with producing a product or delivering a service. The cost of producing a product or service includes the cost of acquiring the raw materials needed to produce the product and the cost of labor. The cost of providing a service includes the cost of the time of those providing the service and the cost of training and developing those providing the service. The cost of the product or service, which includes the cost of acquiring raw materials and of labor, is called cost of goods sold (COGs).
Costs include salaried employees, hourly employees, contractors, and freelancers. It includes all of the costs directly attributable to production and all of the indirect costs of production. The cost of goods sold is a product’s value relative to its competitors. It is the total expense incurred in producing a product or service. Thus, if a company produces a product at a price of $10, then the value of that product is $20.

ALTH NURSING 101 HAYWOOD COLLGE Theories of Nursing Paper This paper will highlight several different aspects of the theories of nanci-Booth and Huber. First there will be a discussion of several different nursing theories such as: Watson’s theory, Carper’s models of nursing, and Huber’s model. These different models are going to be critiqued and compared, and a choice or one chosen to be explained. After each theory model has been addressed, there will be a discussion of the importance of being a theory-guided nurse in our society. In relation to nanci-Booth’s conceptual model, it is used as a reflection of an individuals values, beliefs, and actions. It serves as an assessment, and it is used to look into health promotion. This theory was developed by an American nurse named nanci booth in 1992. The conceptual models helps to define, integrate, and predict the outcome of caring behavior. The caring process and the nurse as a caring person, as a caring healer, as a healing agent, and nursing care are the main concepts used when explaining this process. The steps of the caring process are the nurse as a caring person, which involves caring for self and caring for other. Then the assessment of patient needs is important, and then there is the interdisciplinary collaboration, and then after care or reassessment of the needs of the patient. There are several different outcomes when using the caring process that will be discussed, such as: 1. Caring environment 2. Caring knowledge 3. Caring practice 4. Caring person 5. Caring action 6. Interpersonal relationship 7. Self-awareness The caring process goes hand in hand with the theory of caring. The theory of caring was created by Jean Watson, an American theorist that lived from 1940 to the present. The theoretical framework is the use of ten carative factors that are used in the caring process. These different carative features include: a) a genuine value that shows compassion, love, affection, and caring to the individuals that are in need. b) a holistic knowledge of the individual being cared for as a whole person, and not focusing on just the physical needs, but also the social, spiritual, and intellectual needs of the individual. c) The use of effective communication to show caring; caring actions and touch are used, and there is a desire for an open and trusting relationship. d) there is sensitivity to nonverbal means of communication, and the needs to listen to the patient without making judgements of the individual is important. e) Attention to the physical, behavioral, cultural, and spiritual needs of the individual is essential. f) There is the acknowledgment, appreciation, acceptance, validation, empathetic sensitivity, and respect of the indivudal. The last five factors need to be present in the health care setting. g) The individual needs to be aware of their own perceptions and emotions as well as the perceptions and needs of the patients. h) There is the use of techniques to support the healing process and maintaining the sense of caring. i) Include, but not be limited to the interpersonal processes, verbal and nounl communication, silence, laughter, touch, and music. j) The use of hope as well as the ability to see beyond the fear of death. k) There is the recognition of the need for spiritual support for the individual. This way, the individual will be well-balanced in mind, heart, body, and spirit. In Huber’s adaptation theory, the nursing task to the individuals needs are to be carried out. The five levels of nursing care are the levels of adaptation and can be remembered by the motto that was created by Eunice Huber, which means that the nurse is a person of adaptive force. Level one helps to increase the individual’s ability to adapt, and this is done by anticipating changes and developing plans of care. Level two is done by working with the individual to prevent possible adverse reactions that the individual may experience when placed in an adverse environment. Level three helps to eliminate adverse reactions and to control the situation when the individual’s ablilty to adapt is low. The individual will be prepared to adapt and to accept change. Level four is done by the nurse showing support as the individual may experience grief and loss or trauma. Level five is an individual’s adaptation and return to prior levels of functioning. The goal of nursing is to have the person back to the level that they were able to function prior to an event that has changed their status. Huber’s model is an extension of the Maslow’s hierarchy of needs, and it also is an extension of the Arrow’s theory. The person experiencing illness or grief will be moved to a new level of functioning. The model is cyclical; it repeats itself until the person finds the way to get out of the adverse environment and get to a better state. I believe that, as a nurse, I can use the conceptual model, the adaptation process that I have learned from Huber’s theory when caring for the individuals during his or her time of need, illness, or grief. The theories of nancie booth and Huber explain what a nurse as a person needs to do in order to care for others. These theories go hand in hand and both play important roles in the assessment for the individuals that are in need. For instance, one nurse may go beyond the call of duty and treat the individual as if they are the patient and not the individuals. Being a theory-guided nurse is very important in a society like ours, where so much is changing and so many different things are happening every day. We need theory-guided nurses, especially in nursing homes, in retirement homes, and in places that care for the elderly or disabled. Without theory-guided nurses, society will fall apart and everything that is important to us will fall apart. The more that there is theory-guided nurses in our world, the more that the people will trust other people, and the healthier our country will be. Figure 10.4 gives a pictorial representation of an electricity grid, showing sources of generation, transmission lines, and consumers. The pictured line represents Ampacity and Capacity are two key measures of the output of transmission lines. How do they differ? A Ampacity (the maximum amperage that can travel along the wire) is normally lower than the maximum capacity, in order to withstand voltage drops. These voltages are called drop values and can be significant (voltage differences up to 10% of rated voltage are common). Typically 20% drop is allowed. Because amperage and voltage are interrelated, to reduce the drop along the line, the line is generally larger than needed to handle the current requirements at capacity. (The current varies approximately with the square of the drop in voltage.) In fact the line can be significantly oversized, and the amount of time the line is operated at more than 85% of ampacity is small. The drop in current for a lower-capacity line is less than that of larger-capacity line. In addition, lower-capacity lines can handle short-term increases to ampacity levels without serious consequences. If a low-capacity line must be overloaded for a long period, stress may be placed on both the conductors and insulators or on the insulators alone. (This assumes that the system does not include circuit breakers, and that it is not an underground line.) Typically, an underground line is not as expensive as an overhead line to build and maintain, but they tend to be much more expensive during operations. Capacity refers to the maximum amount of electricity or power, or electrical energy, that can go along a wire. An electrical capacity is the maximum amount of electrical charge that can be passed per second through a conductor. Higher capacity wires tend to be more expensive because they cost more per unit length than low-capacity wires. However, there are some cases where this is not true, for example, transmission lines to remote areas where a lower-capacity, high-voltage line of less cost than a higher capacity line offers better economics. Also, low-capacity, low-voltage wires often have very low capacities because they use only small aluminum cable that is not suited to carrying large currents for very long distances. Natural Sciences Research
Shimkonyi, James O.; Fowler, Joseph W.; Pruett, Danny M.; Behling, Ron; McCaulley, Ronnie B.
The Office of Naval Research, Global (ONRG) is the primary office within ONR that funds scientific research and advanced technology development programs in support of US Navy and Marine Corps missions. The ONRG Research Direction (RD) for Fiscal Year (FY) 2016 emphasizes two critical themes: the first addresses novel, unmanned swarms to include marine, aerial, and space systems; and the second addresses critical human capabilities through augmented perception and cognition. We focus our effort in the areas of cyber resilient cognitive systems and advanced technology swarms as the key areas ONRG is pursuing under the direction, and describe the role of applied math and computational science in supporting advances in swarms and cognitive computing. In addition, we examine trends and implications for science and technology, with particular attention to emerging global scientific programs and strategic initiatives supporting advances in science and technology. We include the ONRG program and budget, as well as highlight a few research program examples of our supported science and technology base.
Investing in environmental research
A comprehensive environmental and public health infrastructure in the United States is critical to the nation's quality of life and economic well-being, the federal government and independent experts agree. But this infrastructure is threatened by a dwindling federal investment in environmental research and training needed to solve the most serious environmental problems of the 21st century. The federal government is spending far less on climate research than it did three decades ago and is falling far short of the research needs of state and local agencies that regulate air pollution. The federal government funds only two-thirds the level necessary to train the next generation of environmental scientists, managers, and experts. The federal commitment to research has shrunk so much that scientists are struggling to address environmental challenges and public officials are finding it difficult to regulate pollution because the research base hasn't expanded to include state-of-the-art technologies. Environmental research is one of the few federal areas where a dedicated tax has proven successful.
Experimental Space Research (ESR) was created by the 1958 National Aeronautics and Space Act to establish scientific expertise and facilities for conducting fundamental research pertaining to space and aeronautical propulsion in the interest of national defense and to encourage industrial technology transfer. This brochure was distributed by the Office of Public Affairs, Office of Aeronautics and Space Technology, Naval Air Development Command (now the Office of Naval Research [ONR]) and was a supplement to the ONR Fiscal Year 1965 Budget. Since the brochure was produced, ESR has been renamed the Space Research Division, but the programs and facilities still operate under the same name.

Advances in computer science and computing research.
Chellapilla, Sreenivasa R; Srivastava, Sanjay C; Thota, Nagendra C
As our knowledge in computer science is advancing rapidly, our research has also been changing rapidly to address new challenges in an ever-changing environment, which poses interesting research questions. We are in a position of witnessing a paradigm shift from the traditional to the nontraditional computing, which is not easy for some researchers. This special issue presents the latest findings in the areas of computer science and computing research with the goal to bring emerging challenges to the forefront of researchers and motivate them to explore advanced ways of modeling, analyzing and solving them.
On the application of science and technology to the conservation of threatened wildlife, with particular emphasis on the black-footed ferret (Mustela nigripes eremina)
Dale, R.E.; Bridges, W.C.
We believe a major obstacle to the conservation of threatened species is the paucity of data on them, especially their ecology and health. Improvement of that situation is a major objective of the research program described, which is an effort to improve the health of the black-footed ferret (Mustela nigripes eremina) population presently confined to a few small populations in the northern Great Plains.

The Department of Energy (DOE) has developed a sustainable biofuels system to replace fossil fuels with renewable resources in an integrated biorefinery system, providing a long term future for U.S. industrial capacity. The DOE mission is to: (1) reduce U.S. dependence on imported crude oil and fossil fuels, and (2) increase the nation's energy security by producing a renewable replacement for conventional fuel blendstocks that can be mixed with petroleum based fuels at high volumetric ratios. The Bioenergy Technologies Office supports the development of this integrated biorefinery system through strategic investments in feedstocks, and research and development of conversion technologies. The mission of each individual DOE Laboratory is clearly aligned with achieving these shared overall DOE Bioenergy goals. Thus, DOE Research Labs have already been supporting biofuels research in a variety of areas, as described below. Research support can be seen in both the Science Research Institutes (SRIs), which consist of the Office of Science Laboratories, and the Engineering Research and Development Laboratories.

Development of Natural Gas Research Program (NGRP)
Zarger, R.
The natural gas research is a part of the DOE's Nuclear Energy for New Generation Research Program (NER). The NGRP program is now two years old and the results of the first year of research are discussed. The major findings of the first year are as follows. Natural gas resources: 1) A map showing the estimated occurrence and the amount of known undiscovered resources of natural gas in the different geologic environments within the North American continent has been produced by the DOE using sophisticated computer graphics. 2) The research in resource potential and availability is still in its very early stages. Future research would concentrate on the resource potential and availability for natural gas conversion to hydrogen fuel for hydrogen economy, and new uses for natural gas. Economics and development of technological pathways to hydrogen: The economics of this program depend on the development of technologies to reduce conversion costs, and to develop, test, and demonstrate the concept of cost effective hydrogen production facilities based on gasification processes and fuel cell systems. Future research would concentrate on the production of hydrogen economics based on natural gas and cost effective technologies. Hydrogen storage and safety: The research focused in the use of safe storage systems for hydrogen using cryogenics for long term storage at low pressure. The most important future research is to investigate cryogenic storage for automotive hydrogen storage at high pressures. Applications: Research was conducted for the identification of application areas for hydrogen fuel that can be developed and deployed within the next 10 years.
